author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Dommaraju Gukesh, 18, Becomes Youngest World Chess Champion
description: It had been an unexpectedly close contest in Singapore with Ding Liren. When he won, the normally stoic Gukesh clasped his hands at the board and burst into tears.
content: Dommaraju Gukesh, an 18-year-old Indian grandmaster, captured the World Chess Championship in Singapore on Thursday by winning the last game of his match against the reigning champion, Ding Liren of China. In so doing, Gukesh became the 18th and youngest undisputed world champion in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Patel’s Warm Senate Welcome Reflects the G.O.P.’s Turn Against the F.B.I.
description: Senate Republicans have largely embraced President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick to run the bureau, demonstrating that his anti-F.B.I. stance is now party orthodoxy.
content: Kash Patel, President-elect Trump’s pick to lead the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has called the top ranks of the bureau “a threat to the people” and published a list of enemies, vowing retribution for investigations of top Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: Ready for the Next Extreme-Weather Catastrophe? Here’s How to Pack a ‘Go Bag.’
description: If the trend continues, extreme weather will occur more frequently. Here’s how experts suggest you prepare.
content: Extreme weather is happening more frequently across the country, as we have seen this year with Hurricane Helene’s catastrophic impact on Asheville, N.C., November’s wildfires in New York and New Jersey and this month’s fast-spreading Malibu fire. Nearly 20 percent of all Americans have had to evacuate their homes because of unexpected severe weather, according to a new study by the analytics firm YouGov.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clara Bingham
title: Birth Control’s (First) Civil War
description: In “The Icon and the Idealist,” Stephanie Gorton tells the story of two women who fought a patriarchal system — and each other.
content: In the days after Donald Trump’s election, abortion pill providers were inundated with orders for Mifepristone and Misoprostol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, David E. Sanger, Stella Tan, Mary Wilson, Maria Byrne, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: How China Hacked America’s Phone Network
description: It’s an alarming new breach, and its scope demonstrates the growing power of one of the United States’ biggest adversaries.
content: An alarming new hack by China has penetrated the nerve center of the United States: its telephone network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Tan
title: YouTube TV Raises Monthly Charge 14 Percent, to $82.99
description: The increase is the latest for the streaming service, which debuted in 2017 at $35 a month. The company blamed “rising content costs.”
content: YouTube TV is becoming more expensive — again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Best Art of 2024
description: This was a year whose high points included Joan Jonas’s luminous survey, the extravaganza “PST ART,” and the 24-karat beauty of a show “Siena: The Rise of Painting, 1300-1350.”
content: Art-wise, 2024 had an in-between-things vibe. It was a year of big-deal biennials, but the consensus was that none delivered much firepower. There was a lot of talk about money — what sold for what, and to whom — but no radically record-busting news. In general, the institutional art world veered, as it always does, between uplift (some strong museum shows) and cringe (the $6.2 million banana). I’ll go mostly with uplift in the (unranked) list of highlights below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Brinkhurst-Cuff
title: Is Facial Hair the Last Taboo in Women’s Beauty?
description: Millions of women regularly remove it. Does it have to be that way?
content: The day before Rosemary Greenwood’s first wedding, in 1984, she sat in her backyard in the gleaming sun with a mirror and tweezers. For over two hours she plucked hairs off her face. “Not the way most brides spend the day before their wedding,” said Greenwood, 69. She had often considered bringing up her struggles with her facial hair with friends, but never mustered the courage. “Pretending that none of us had this issue, which of course was ridiculous. The silence made it shameful.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Power, Intimidation and the Resurrection of Trump’s Support for Hegseth
description: The president-elect became convinced that letting Pete Hegseth fail would set off a feeding frenzy among senators. What followed was a MAGA swarm that helped salvage his bid, at least for now.
content: Just last week, Pete Hegseth was twisting in the wind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: How Do You Stay Focused on an Important Task?
description: Do you find it hard to concentrate? What can we learn from a Formula 1 driver’s mental tool kit?
content: Are you easily distracted? When you have a homework assignment to complete, a book to read, an instrument to practice or a room to clean, is it easy for you to stay focused and do it, or does your mind wander so that you often end up performing the task poorly?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Victor Brombert, Princeton Scholar With a Secret Army Past, Dies at 101
description: As a Jewish teen, he fled the Nazis for America — then landed at D-Day and swept across Europe in a unit that gathered intelligence. Its work was hidden for decades.
content: Victor Brombert, a respected scholar of comparative literature who late in life revealed that he had worked for a secret American intelligence program in World War II, which took him to D-Day, the liberation of Paris and the Battle of the Bulge, died on Nov. 26 at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: The Most Memorable Wines of 2024
description: The scarcity and fragility of rare old bottles makes them naturally memorable, but these 12 younger wines had their own unforgettable charms.
content: I’ve had the privilege of drinking some wonderful wines this year, including a few rare, breathtakingly gorgeous old bottles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On a Treadmill
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Commutes the Sentences of 1,500 Americans, a Record for One Day
description: Most of those being granted clemency had been placed in home confinement during the pandemic. Some Republicans have tried to push legislation that would have forced those people to return to prison.
content: President Biden said on Thursday that he is commuting the sentences of nearly 1,500 people and pardoning 39 people convicted of nonviolent crimes in a sweeping act of clemency during his final weeks in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Clarke Reed, Who Helped the G.O.P. Conquer the South, Dies at 96
description: He built Mississippi’s Republican Party into a conservative powerhouse, making himself a regional power broker in the process.
content: Clarke Reed, a courtly Mississippi conservative who pushed his state’s Republican Party from irrelevance to dominance in the 1970s and helped lead the charge in turning the South from deep blue to ruby red, died on Sunday at his home in Greenville, Miss. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: F.A.A. Administrator Will Resign Before Trump Takes Office
description: Mike Whitaker, who runs the Federal Aviation Administration, is leaving the leadership position after serving only one year of a five-year term.
content: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration, Mike Whitaker, announced on Thursday that he is stepping down at the end of the President Biden’s term, leaving the agency without crucial leadership as ongoing safety challenges and questions about oversight of Boeing persist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf and Houman Barekat
title: The Highs and Lows on London Stages in 2024
description: Our critics discuss which A-lister performances on the West End were worth the ticket price, and why so many new musicals struggled this year.
content: This year saw London host buzzy productions like Jamie Lloyd’s “Romeo and Juliet,” starring Tom Holland and Francesca Amewudah-Rivers, and Robert Icke’s take on “Oedipus,” with Mark Strong and Lesley Manville. Other productions struggled, including more star vehicles — and some musicals, particularly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: F.T.C. Sues Largest U.S. Alcohol Distributor for Illegal Pricing
description: The suit, under a long-dormant antitrust law, accuses Southern Glazer’s of charging small businesses “drastically” more than big chains.
content: With just six weeks left in office, the Biden administration announced a new push, using an old law, to crack down on anticompetitive business practices.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Jan. 8, 2025
description: What do you notice about book bans across the United States?
content: Note: We will live-moderate a discussion about this graph on Wednesday, Jan. 8, 2025, and then post the graph’s Reveal by the morning of Friday, Jan. 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: How to Make Sense of the Fluoride Debate
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has said he wants to curb water fluoridation nationwide. Here’s what the science shows about the benefits and the risks.
content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s skepticism about fluoride has become a focal point in the debate about whether he’s suitable to run the nation’s health department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: European Central Bank Cuts Interest Rates as the Economy Weakens
description: The bank has been lowering rates since June as inflation slowed, but other risks are growing, including the threat of higher tariffs promised by President-elect Donald J. Trump.
content: The European Central Bank lowered interest rates on Thursday, the fourth cut this year amid growing concerns that the region’s economic outlook is darkening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Selena Gomez and Benny Blanco Announce Their Engagement. The Internet Rejoices.
description: The couple, who have been publicly discussing their relationship for a year, were deluged with congratulations on social media.
content: The actor and singer Selena Gomez announced her engagement to Benny Blanco, the record producer and songwriter, in a social media post Wednesday night, and Taylor Swift, one of Gomez’s closest friends, quickly offered to be her flower girl.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Connections Companion No. 551
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Dec. 13, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Rights Groups See a Chance to Seek Justice for Syrian Regime’s Victims
description: It seems unlikely that deposed President Bashar al-Assad, who fled to Russia, will be forced to stand trial. That is not deterring activists who have worked for years to document his government’s crimes.
content: The fall of Syria’s government has breathed new life into a long push for justice over crimes committed by the Assad regime. Now, at last, there is a chance for human rights groups to inspect prison sites, freely interview witnesses and quickly build legal cases for prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Parkin
title: Read This Before Buying That Video Game
description: Big corporations turned video games from an engaging artistic medium into something addictive and gambling-adjacent.
content: When I was a child in the 1990s, I began my campaign for my first video game console several months before Christmas. My parents, like some parents who came before them and most who came after, were wary. They associated video games not so much with the thrilling secrets of Super Mario’s undulating hills or the literary flair of Infocom’s interactive fiction games, but instead with vague ideas of truancy, delinquency and probable ruin. My grandmother, a pragmatic woman, took pity. She secreted under the tree a Game Boy and a copy of the Soviet-era miracle that is Tetris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Man in the White Van’ Review: Sleazy Rider
description: In this derivative thriller, set in the early 1970s, young women are stalked by an anonymous killer.
content: “The Man in the White Van,” loosely based on the exploits of the Florida killer Billy Mansfield Jr., is a flaccid and formulaic thriller more beholden to horror-movie conventions than those of true crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Take a Whiff of Eau de Trump. It Reeks.
description: Like Trump himself, Trump’s new line of fragrances is big on braggadocio, short on details and gaudily packaged.
content: If you could smell like any U.S. president, who would it be?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
description: This week’s properties are in Midtown, on the Upper West Side and in Parkchester.
content: A 603-square-foot studio apartment with white oak floors and cabinets, marble countertops, a double vanity, radiant-heat bathroom floors, a dishwasher, a garbage disposal, a washer/dryer, central air-conditioning and Juliet balconies, on the seventh floor of a 29-story new development with a doorman, a resident manager, a concierge, a roof deck with a pool and cabanas, a spa, a salon, a gym and a private restaurant. Jade Chan, Alexander Boriskin and McKenzie Ryan, Douglas Elliman, 929-751-6900; elliman.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Miglore
title: Is It Safe to Put Hot Food in the Fridge? And More Food Safety Questions, Answered
description: There’s a universal — and easy — answer to a common kitchen predicament.
content: Faced with a steamy pan of food that needs refrigerating — or six, on holidays and other feast days — we may find ourselves in an apparent predicament: Do we wait for the food to cool on the counter (and risk lingering too long at temperatures that let harmful bacteria proliferate)? Or do we rush it to the fridge, potentially warming everything inside?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: How U.S. Firms Battled a Government Crackdown to Keep Tech Sales to China
description: An intense struggle has unfolded in Washington between companies and officials over where to draw the line on selling technology to China.
content: At a meeting in Washington this spring, tech company representatives and government officials once again found themselves at odds over where to draw the line when it came to selling coveted technology to China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel E. Gross
title: An Article on Hysterectomies Asks What Might Have Been Lost
description: Rachel E. Gross, a health reporter, was used to asking tough questions, but here her reporting presented a new challenge: Some patients didn’t know which organs had been removed from their bodies.
content: I first heard Stacia Alexander share her hysterectomy experience in March 2023, on a panel hosted by the group Let’s Talk Menopause. I was stunned by her candor as she recounted being plunged into surgical menopause at the age of 45.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: A New Female Designer Takes Center Stage
description: Bottega Veneta announced that Louise Trotter will replace Matthieu Blazy as creative director.
content: In the fashion equivalent of a nuclear chain reaction, Bottega Veneta announced on Thursday that Matthieu Blazy, its designer of three years and the man who made it into a must-see brand in Milan, was leaving the house. He is expected to become the new designer of Chanel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: N.C. Elections Board Rejects G.O.P. Effort to Toss 60,000 Ballots
description: The ruling comes in a dispute over a State Supreme Court race that the Democratic incumbent won by 734 votes.
content: The North Carolina State Board of Elections rejected on Wednesday a Republican bid to throw out more than 60,000 votes in a closely contested election for a State Supreme Court seat that an incumbent Democrat won by 734 votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Considers Kennedy’s Daughter-in-Law for C.I.A. Deputy Director
description: Amaryllis Fox Kennedy, a former C.I.A. officer who is married to the son of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., raised alarms for publishing a book about her work at the agency without going through a review process.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump is considering Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s daughter-in-law to serve as the deputy director at the C.I.A., according to four people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch: ‘Is Creativity Dead?”
description: Is internet culture killing our creativity? Or, are powerful algorithms just hiding it?
content: Note: This is the last Film and Podcast Club of 2024. Be sure to join us when we return in the new year on Jan. 9.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Aguiar
title: Astro Bot Wins Top Honor at the Game Awards
description: The exploration of Sony history held off Balatro and Metaphor: ReFantazio, which each received several awards at an annual showcase for the industry.
content: The plucky platformer Astro Bot won the top prize at the Game Awards on Thursday, a crowning achievement for a character who originated as an asset for a PlayStation tech demo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson, Mitch Smith, Katie Benner and Amy Julia Harris
title: Health Insurance Workers Fearful Amid Public Anger After Slaying of C.E.O.
description: Employees at UnitedHealthcare and other companies described being anxious after an outpouring of online vitriol.
content: The fatal shooting last week of an executive on the streets of New York City plunged his family members and colleagues into grief. For rank-and-file employees across the health insurance industry, the killing has left them with an additional emotion: fear, with many frightened for their own safety and feeling under attack for their work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: Donald Trump’s Perfect 1980s Day
description: For a man who rose to fame in the gilded yuppie era of New York City, today’s ringing the bell to open the stock exchange, and being named Person of the Year by Time, must have a certain appeal.
content: By many standards, Donald J. Trump has lived a remarkable American life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Politi, Lucía Cholakian Herrera and Ana Ionova
title: In Milei’s Argentina, Economic Albatross Is Tamed but Life Is Much Harder
description: A year after becoming president, Javier Milei has been praised inside and outside Argentina for reining in galloping inflation. But his economic policies have inflicted widespread hardship.
content: At home and abroad, Argentina’s president, Javier Milei, is a man with plenty of fans. And not just any fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Why Some British Pubs Are Running Out of Guinness
description: Guinness’s parent company has limited the amount of the beer that U.K. wholesalers and distributors can buy each week, after surging demand led to fears of shortages.
content: British pubs are facing something of a crisis: They cannot get enough Guinness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Remembering David Bonderman, a Private Equity Pioneer
description: A former lawyer, he cofounded the giant investment firm TPG and became known for complex deals that remade corporate America. He died on Wednesday at 82.
content: David Bonderman, a corporate lawyer who co-founded the giant investment firm TPG and helped transform private equity into a multitrillion-dollar industry that reshaped Wall Street, died on Wednesday morning. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Biden Commuted the Sentences of 1,500 Americans, a One-Day Record
description: Also, Israel said it would stay in Syria for now. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: President Biden announced today that he would pardon 39 people convicted of nonviolent crimes and commute the sentences of 1,499 others. The White House said it was the largest number of commutations by an American president in a single day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: A Black Art Dealer Lent Paintings to a Museum. His Heirs Want Them Back.
description: Dozens of artworks owned by Marshall Marcell have spent the past century with the Louisiana State Museum.
content: In its founding years in the early 20th century, the Louisiana State Museum borrowed dozens of artworks from Marshall Marcell, a successful African American art dealer in New Orleans, to hang on its almost empty walls. More than a century later, Marcell’s descendants say they want them back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Elfin Magic
description: Are all elves magical? Or just some?
content: Jessie writes: This dispute arose during a game of 20 Questions: Does Legolas from “The Lord of the Rings” use magic? I say no. He has inherent elfin capabilities, such as a keen sense of sight and agility — like how birds have hollow bones for flight. My partners believe all elves are magical. One fancies themself an expert because they read “The Silmarillion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: Ocean Heat Wiped Out Half These Seabirds Around Alaska
description: About four million common murres were killed by a domino effect of ecosystem changes, and the population is showing no signs of recovery, according to new research.
content: The first evidence was the feathered bodies washing up on Alaskan beaches. They were common murres, sleek black-and-white seabirds that typically spend months at a time away from land. But in 2015 and 2016, officials tallied 62,000 emaciated corpses from California to Alaska.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Whitney Is Now Free for Those 25 and Under
description: The painter Julie Mehretu donated $2 million to the art museum to encourage young people to visit.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll find out about the Whitney Museum’s plan to expand free admission to those 25 and under. We’ll also get details on a new state law requiring insurance companies to pay for testing for dyslexia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: C.E.O.s Are Tripping
description: Why executives are using psychedelics to get ahead.
content: Psychedelic drugs have come a long way. They once belonged to the counterculture (“tune in, drop out”). Now they are finding a home in the C-suite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Three Questions From Cutting-Edge Climate Science
description: An annual gathering of scientists this week offered a glimpse into the latest efforts to answer some of the most intriguing questions about our warming planet.
content: Every December, more than 25,000 scientists from around the globe descend upon a cavernous convention center to eat dry sandwiches, drink weak coffee and ponder all things Earth and climate and space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Oldest Human Genomes Reveal How a Small Group Burst Out of Africa
description: DNA from European fossils dating back 45,000 years offers new clues to how our species spread across the world.
content: Some 45,000 years ago, a tiny group of people — fewer than 1,000, all told — wandered the icy northern fringes of Europe. Across thousands of miles of tundra, they hunted woolly rhinoceros and other big game. Their skin was most likely dark. To keep warm in the bone-chilling temperatures, they probably wore the hides and furs of the animals they killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Why Do Some Rebel Governments Last When Others Fall?
description: One factor matters most, and it could be a problem in Syria.
content: In Syria, “forever” is over.  The regime of former President Bashar al-Assad, whose supporters once chanted “our leader forever,”  has been deposed by an alliance of rebel groups after a 13-year civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon
title: Report on New Jersey’s Worst Nursing Home Finds Rampant Fraud and Abuse
description: A trio of relatives in New Jersey defrauded the state’s Medicaid program out of millions of dollars while neglecting patient care, the state comptroller found.
content: Three men running a group of nursing homes in New Jersey will be barred from being Medicaid providers after an investigation by the state comptroller’s office found that they were funneling millions of dollars into their personal accounts and other businesses while severely neglecting vulnerable residents in their care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Endless Summer Syndrome’ Review: Who’s Lying?
description: In this sun-dappled French psychological thriller, a lawyer receives a call accusing her husband of having an affair with one of their children.
content: Every year there seems to be a new book or movie on the subject of incest in France — most recently Catherine Breillat’s “Last Summer.” Extending from this tradition, in which a sunny French bourgeois family is secretly rotting from the inside, is “Endless Summer Syndrome,” a promising debut feature by the Iranian director Kaveh Daneshmand that frames the crime as a twisty detective story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Ana Ley
title: How the Resurrected Congestion Pricing Plan Could Die in the Courts
description: Manhattan’s new tolling program is still being challenged in federal and state courts, with rulings possible before it begins on Jan. 5.
content: E-ZPass readers and cameras are in place to start New York City’s congestion pricing program on Jan. 5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: How to Dangerously Misread a Very Important Verdict
description: What happened on that subway train — and the acquittal that followed — deserves a more measured response.
content: Since Monday, when a jury found Daniel Penny not guilty in the death of Jordan Neely on a New York City subway, the conversation has threatened to go off the rails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Under Trump, Voice of America Journalists Fear Politicization
description: Donald J. Trump’s choice of Kari Lake to lead Voice of America goes against recent efforts to shield the federally funded news organization from politicization.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice of Kari Lake to serve as the director of the federally funded broadcaster Voice of America sent a chill through the ranks of the organization, where journalists expressed anxiety about Ms. Lake and what the future could hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: The Geminids Meteor Shower Is Peaking. Here’s How to Watch.
description: The shower forms from the debris of an asteroid and peaks this weekend. But a nearly full moon could interfere with viewing.
content: Our universe might be chock-full of cosmic wonder, but you can observe only a fraction of astronomical phenomena with your naked eye. Meteor showers, natural fireworks that streak brightly across the night sky, are one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Simon and Jonathan Stevenson
title: What Trump Could Do to the U.S. Military
description: Americans have counted on the indispensability of a constitutionally alert military. Will that continue?
content: President-elect Donald Trump and members of his transition team have reportedly considered plans to fire Gen. C.Q. Brown, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and senior officers connected to former Gen. Mark Milley, and to potentially ensure the promotion of senior officers based on their personal loyalty to the president. These would be radical moves, well outside the boundaries of standard Pentagon procedures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: Perfect Instant Ramen
description: That’s what you get when you add an egg, a pat of butter and a slice or two of American cheese to a bowl of steaming noodles.
content: In 2021, I asked a bunch of chefs and food personalities about their favorite instant ramen for New York Magazine’s The Strategist. Lucas Kwan Peterson, the former food columnist for The Los Angeles Times, astutely pointed out that “there’s usually (but not always) a direct correlation between the number of sachets of different things — oils, sauces, powders, dried veggies — included in a package and how good it is. The more, the better!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Labor Board Classifies ‘Love Is Blind’ Contestants as Employees
description: The National Labor Relations Board’s case against the Netflix hit could have ripple effects across the reality TV industry.
content: The National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint against the hit reality show “Love Is Blind” on Wednesday in which it classified the show’s contestants as employees, opening a case that could have ripple effects across the reality television industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Rebel Group’s Terrorist Label Could Hinder Efforts to Aid Syria
description: The United States and others call Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, now taking power in Syria, a terrorist group, blocking funding and even contact with the group. Experts say that should change.
content: A few weeks ago, world leaders likely were not thinking about Hayat Tahrir al-Sham and its designation as a terrorist organization. But now, the rebel faction that drove a surprise offensive that toppled the Assad regime is Syria’s de facto government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Chanel Fills the Hottest Job in Fashion
description: Matthieu Blazy is getting the coveted post. Here’s how it went down.
content: The hottest job in fashion has finally been filled. After six months without an artistic director, Chanel, the second largest luxury fashion brand in the world and the only couture house in the top three, has named a new designer: Matthieu Blazy. Most recently the man behind Bottega Veneta, Mr. Blazy will be in charge of all fashion, couture and accessories for Chanel, creating 10 collections a year. He will make his debut next October during the Paris shows.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Perfect Takeout for a Night In

content: The city of Louisville and the Justice Department reached an agreement on Thursday to address misconduct by the local police after the fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor in 2020 brought attention to far-ranging abuses by law enforcement.

author: By Stephanie Saul and Vimal Patel
title: D.E.I. Official at University of Michigan Is Fired Over Antisemitism Claim, Lawyer Says
description: The official, an administrator of multicultural programs, was accused of making antisemitic remarks in a conversation. Her lawyer said that the school fired her this week, and vowed to sue.

content: Our sun is a violent place. Bursts of radiation snap off the solar surface with the strength of millions of volcanic eruptions. Hot plasma churns and spews, streaming particles that can harm astronauts and satellites in space and damage electrical systems on the ground. They can also brighten up our skies with colorful lights.

author: By Adam H. Graham
title: A Swiss Ski Chalet That Calls to Mind a Spy Movie
description: Plus: a Muji designer’s museum show, deodorant inspired by “The Iliad” and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: If evil villains skied, this cliffhanging lair in Switzerland’s Canton Valais would top their bucket list. From the outside, the new exclusive-use, three-bedroom property opening Dec. 15 looks more like a gondola station than it does a luxury chalet. The geometric fortress of concrete, galvanized steel, chimneys and solar panels sits solitary on a rocky ridge atop the ancient Tortin Glacier at an elevation of 9,500 feet. Its cantilevered glass windows reflect the surrounding pink alpenglow and bluebird skies that the 4 Vallées Ski area — Switzerland’s largest, including Verbier — is known for. Inside, the mind-clearing Scandinavian minimalism of the Norwegian architect Snorre Stinessen focuses on the elements with a blond wood grain ceiling, sauna and log fireplace. The ski-in, ski-out accessibility is off-piste, ensuring discreet and quick getaways. But fear not: Dog sleds and caterpillar-tracked buggies for those less active can be arranged by the staff, as can wine-pairing meals, massages and an emergency oxygen supply, just in case the plan for world domination fails. From about $68,000 for three nights for six people with full board; when not occupied, a self-catering option is available from about $2,260 per night, cabanetortin.com.

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘September 5’ Review: When the Munich Games Changed Our News
description: Tim Fehlbaum’s journalism procedural, starring Peter Sarsgaard, tracks the broadcast coverage of the terrorist attack at the 1972 Olympics.
content: A tense ethical showdown with the racing pulse of a thriller, “September 5” revisits the day in 1972 when the Munich Olympics became a very different kind of international spectacle. Before dawn that morning, while many of the world’s elite athletes were still sleeping in the Olympic Village or drunkenly heading for bed, eight heavily armed members of Black September, a militant Palestinian group, easily scrambled over a perimeter fence in the village. They quickly made their way to the building where the Israeli delegation was housed and took 11 of its members hostage, shooting two men, who soon died.

They’re in a large dining room crowded with children of varying sizes, shapes and bearings, and while some seem to be on the cusp of manhood, many look too obscenely young to be here.
